title: 120-E
statement: E. Put Knight!time limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputinput.txtoutputoutput.txtPetya and Gena play a very interesting game "Put a Knight!" on a chessboardn×nin size. In this game they take turns to put chess pieces called "knights" on the board so that no two knights could threat each other. A knight located in square(r,c)can threat squares(r- 1,c+ 2),(r- 1,c- 2),(r+ 1,c+ 2),(r+ 1,c- 2),(r- 2,c+ 1),(r- 2,c- 1),(r+ 2,c+ 1)and(r+ 2,c- 1)(some of the squares may be located outside the chessboard). The player who can't put a new knight during his move loses. Determine which player wins considering that both players play optimally well and Petya starts.InputThe first line contains integerT(1 ≤T≤ 100) — the number of boards, for which you should determine the winning player. NextTlines containTintegersni(1 ≤ni≤ 10000) — the sizes of the chessboards.OutputFor eachni×niboard print on a single line "0" if Petya wins considering both players play optimally well. Otherwise, print "1".ExamplesInput221Output10

processed.result:
You are given a number of chessboards, each of size $n \times n$. Two players take turns placing knights on the board. A knight on a square can attack other knights on eight specific squares (like a real chess knight).  The game continues until a player cannot place a knight without attacking an existing one. Determine which player wins if both players play perfectly. 

Input:

The first line contains the number of chessboards, $T$. 
The next $T$ lines each contain an integer $n$, the size of a chessboard.

Output:

For each chessboard size $n$, print "0" if Player 1 wins, and "1" if Player 2 wins.

Two players take turns placing pieces on a square board.  A piece can attack other pieces in a specific pattern. The first player to be unable to place a piece loses. Determine which player wins if both players play perfectly.
